author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/103042#issuecomment-2002516943 still applies. Also, the `Ext` suffix has the connotation of extension modules, which might be problematic.

P.S.: on that note: the code in this package might actually be suited for an extension module inside one of your existing packages.

Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->
If this package has a sufficiently wide scope to warrant being an independent package, a name like `ControllerDesignPyPlots` might be suitable.

> [#103042 (comment)](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/103042#issuecomment-2002516943) still applies. Also, the `Ext` suffix has the connotation of extension modules, which might be problematic.
> 
> P.S.: on that note: the code in this package might actually be suited for an extension module inside one of your existing packages.

No. I do not have any other plotting package and also no general control package where this could be added.

I don't think it is possible to add this code to PyPlot because I overwrite the display() function, and my plot functions return a different type compared to PyPlot. So while I understand your concerns, I think I need to create a new package to achieve the following feature:
- possibility to store plots in an high-level format (with the possibility to zoom in, change the header etc) on disk and to display these plots after loading from disk automatically

I intend to to add a package extension for Bode plots etc, because they would need ControlSystemsBase as dependency which a a huge dependency and not needed otherwise.

I need this package to make plotting easy for students, and I think it can be useful for others. 

And a name like "ControllerDesignPyPlots" is too limiting, because plots for people who migrate from Simulink to Julia can also be very useful for people who are not doing control design.

OK, I could consider a name like `EditablePlots` if you think that better matches the key new idea of this package...
[noblock]

> OK, I could consider a name like `EditablePlots` if you think that better matches the key new idea of this packageâ€¦

Yes, I think a more descriptive name would be good. If the package is specific to `PyPlot`, I'd include that in the name (`EditablePyPlots`). If it might extend to other backends in the future, something like `EditablePlots` would be fine.

I'm not actually quite sure what the idea of the package is, though. Looking at the README, the example

> ```
> p = plot(X, Y, xlabel="X", ylabel="sin", fig="basic")
> ```
> 
> You can now close the plot window. You can re-display the plot by typing:
>
> ```
> p
> ```

already works with standard `Plots.jl`. Likewise, dumping and reloading `p` to a file via JLD2. If the goal is, as you say,

> possibility to store plots in an high-level format (with the possibility to zoom in, change the header etc) on disk and to display these plots after loading from disk automatically

that's already built-in, and then I don't understand then mae `EditablePlots` .

I couldn't try out `PyPlotExt` directly because `PyPlot` just segfaults on my machine (I find [`PythonCall`](https://github.com/JuliaPy/PythonCall.jl) to be a much more robust way of calling `matplotlib`). Based on the proposed name `EditablePlots` I'm assuming that in your package, `p` is some kind of mutable object that can be "edited" to modify the plot, not just a  `Plots.Plot` object? If that's the case, `EditablePlots`/`EditablePyPlots` seems like a good name, but you'd want to update the README to show the actual feature of the package.

> I couldn't try out `PyPlotExt` directly because `PyPlot` just segfaults on my machine (I find [`PythonCall`](https://github.com/JuliaPy/PythonCall.jl) to be a much more robust way of calling `matplotlib`). Based on the proposed name `EditablePlots` I'm assuming that in your package, `p` is some kind of mutable object that can be "edited" to modify the plot, not just a `Plots.Plot` object? If that's the case, `EditablePlots`/`EditablePyPlots` seems like a good name, but you'd want to update the README to show the actual feature of the package.

I will rename the package again, but I don't know to which name, could be EditiablePlots or ControlPlots...

Don't merge this one.
